pullRequest.body:
This PR adds a new file `NumberTheory.LSeries.Dirichlet` that contains results on L-series of specific functions:
* the Möbius function
* Dirichlet characters, with the constant function `1` as a special case
* the arithmetic function `ζ` (which has the same L-series as the constant function `1`)
* the von Mangoldt function and its twists by Dirichlet characters

It also adds (L-series of zero and of the indicator function of `{1}`) and removes (convergence of the L-series of the constant function `1` / of  `ζ`; this is moved to the new file) some material to/from `NumberTheory.LSeries.Basic`.

See [this thread on Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/144837-PR-reviews/topic/L-series/near/424858837).

---

nodes.body: LGTM!

It might be a good idea to apply Ruben's suggestion, changing `(h : ∀ {n} (_ : n ≠ 0), f n = g n)` to `(h : ∀ {n} (_ : n ≠ 0), f n = g n)`, not just to `term_congr` but to the other 7 lemmas which use this formulation.

Looks great!

Thanks!

This isn't complete, I still need to read the last bit of the file, but I'm stopping for lunch now

```suggestion
lemma LSeries_twist_vonMangoldt_eq {N : ℕ} (χ : DirichletCharacter ℂ N) {s : ℂ} (hs : 1 < s.re) :
```

```suggestion
lemma LSeriesSummable_twist_vonMangoldt {N : ℕ} (χ : DirichletCharacter ℂ N) {s : ℂ}
    (hs : 1 < s.re) : LSeriesSummable (↗χ * ↗Λ) s :=
  LSeriesSummable_mul χ <| LSeriesSummable_vonMangoldt hs
```
(I think either is fine)
huh interesting, I though one always tried to reduce the number of lines (not that in this case it makes a big difference).
I prefer to have the statement on a separate line when the (name and) arguments span more than one line, to visually separate the two.
it looks weird to me to have this, but I guess there isn't a simp lemma one can write to deal with this in general.
I have inlined this now in the next proof (which is the only place where it is used).

```suggestion
  ext
  simp_rw [← natCoe_apply, ← intCoe_apply, coe_mul, coe_zeta_mul_coe_moebius, one_apply, delta]
```
Maybe additionally `left_ne_zero_of_mem_divisorsAntidiagonal`, `right_ne_zero_of_mem_divisorsAntidiagonal`
OK.
Sort these please
Tell that to `#minimize_imports`! :smile:

```suggestion
  refine ⟨fun H ↦ ?_, LSeriesSummable_of_bounded_of_one_lt_re (m := 1) fun n ↦ ?_⟩
```

This seems worth extracting; for example with
```lean
theorem moebius_apply_eq (n : ℕ) : μ n = 0 ∨ μ n = 1 ∨ μ n = -1 := by
  simp only [moebius, coe_mk]
  split_ifs
  · right
    exact neg_one_pow_eq_or ..
  · left
    rfl

theorem abs_moebius_le_one {n : ℕ} : |μ n| ≤ 1 := by
  obtain h|h|h := moebius_apply_eq n <;> simp [h]

theorem moebius_ne_zero_iff_eq_or {n : ℕ} : μ n ≠ 0 ↔ μ n = 1 ∨ μ n = -1 := by
  have := moebius_apply_eq n
  aesop
#align nat.arithmetic_function.moebius_ne_zero_iff_eq_or ArithmeticFunction.moebius_ne_zero_iff_eq_or
```
Maybe, but I think this should be a separate PR.
It seems Ruben opened #11770 for this. I attempted to send it to be merged, but this did not get the reaction I had hoped for.
I've merged master and used `abs_moebius_le_one` to golf this proof.

```suggestion
    simp_rw [← natCoe_apply, ← intCoe_apply, coe_mul, coe_zeta_mul_coe_moebius]
```
OK. (Very slightly slower, though.)
If you move `mul_delta` up, you can use it in the previous lemma
OK; it simplifies the last line in the proof a bit.

Slightly shorter:
```suggestion
  · simp_rw [CharP.cast_eq_zero, MulCharClass.map_nonunit χ not_isUnit_zero, delta, if_false]
```
OK (also ~200 heartbeats slower).

Could be:
```suggestion
  rw [χ.level_one, MulChar.one_apply (isUnit_of_subsingleton _), Pi.one_apply]
```

```suggestion
  rw [← LSeries_convolution' (zeta_LSeriesSummable_iff.mpr hs) (LSeriesSummable_moebius_iff.mpr hs),
```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion rw [← LSeries_convolution' (LSeriesSummable_zeta_iff.mpr hs) (LSeriesSummable_moebius_iff.mpr hs)] ```
The the line will be too long...

```suggestion
    simp only [Nat.left_ne_zero_of_mem_divisorsAntidiagonal hp, ↓reduceIte]
```

I'd go for
```suggestion
lemma ArithmeticFunction.const_one_eq_zeta {R : Type*} [Semiring R] (n : ℕ) (hn : n ≠ 0) :
    (1 : ℕ → R) n = (ζ ·) n := by
  simp only [Pi.one_apply, zeta_apply, hn, ↓reduceIte, cast_one]
```
but I'd also make `n` implicit - this would probably require doing the same to the arguments to `convolution_congr`
OK. For consistency, I've adapted the arguments of all congruence lemmas involving L-series and related stuff. (But it would be even better if `∀ n ≠ 0, ...` would read as `∀ {n} (_ : n ≠ 0), ...`.)

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (1 : ℕ → R) n = (ζ ·) n := by ```

```suggestion
  have ⟨hp₁, hp₂⟩ := ne_zero_of_mem_divisorsAntidiagonal hp
```
(and also at line 103)
OK. I'm now opening `Nat` throughout the file, which allows to remove a few more prefixes.

Non-German-speakers might not be immediately aware that `Moebius` and `Möbius` are the same, so I think we should probably standardize on one or the other. The "oe" spelling seems much more frequent, although not universal, in existing mathlib code so I suggest using that. (It is a job for another PR to bring the existing "ö" spellings into line.)

As a rule, I would prefer spelling names as they are written in the person's language (at least when it uses latin script). I think the "oe" spelling was used historically because "ö" was not readily avaiable on non-German typewriters/keyboards, but nowadays we have basically all variations of latin letters available, and so there is really no good reason anymore to not write "Möbius" (or "Gödel", "Gröbner", "Teichmüller", "Gauß", "Poincaré" etc.).

I'd be willing to at least submit a PR standardizing "Möbius" throughout Mathlib.
(In declaration names, it is a different matter, of course.)
OK, fair enough – not something we need to resolve here.

```suggestion
  refine (h.indicator {n | n.Prime}).congr (fun n ↦ ?_)
```
(speeds up this entire proof by a factor of 3)
In terms of heartbeats, it is almost a factor of 5. I've noticed that `convert` can sometimes be slow...

```suggestion
  · simp only [Pi.neg_apply, Set.indicator_of_mem hn, term_of_ne_zero hn.ne_zero, 
      moebius_apply_prime hn, cpow_one, push_cast]
    ring
```

This makes it a bit slower again, though. With `neg_div` in the `simp only`, `ring` is not necessary, but it is still slightly slower, presumably because of the `push_cast` simp set. But I think the proof is cleaner that way, so I'm changing it.
this can be deleted (EDIT: "this" meant the `norm_cast` call, which doesn't really do anything)
Deleting it makes the proof also noticeably faster.
Just out of interest, why is this given a name? It doesn't seem to be used anywhere.

I think I've read somewhere that notations should be given names, so I did that for a while.
But I have to admit that I don't really know why (or if this is really a rule of some sort).

I feel this should perhaps be the other way around: if it is to be used as a rewrite lemma, then we will probably want to rewrite the (current) RHS into the LHS (as in both of the usages later in this PR)
Good point. (The proof didn't even need changing.)

```

```

  simp only [χ.map_nonunit this, delta, hn', ↓reduceIte]
```

```suggestion
  refine fun h ↦ Real.not_summable_indicator_one_div_natCast hN 1 ?_
```
this comment is just the current goal, was it meant to be deleted?

golf:
````
rw [norm_term_eq, one_re, Real.rpow_one, Set.indicator]
  split_ifs with h1 h2
  · rw [h2, cast_zero, div_zero]
  · rw [h1, χ.map_one, norm_one]
  all_goals positivity
````

golf:
```suggestion
  exact not_LSeriesSummable_at_one hN χ <| LSeriesSummable.of_re_le_re (by simp [h]) H
```
`by simp only [one_re, h]` is faster and still fits on the line.

```suggestion
  refine .of_norm <| h.norm.of_nonneg_of_le (fun _ ↦ norm_nonneg _) (fun n ↦ norm_term_le s ?_)
  rw [Pi.mul_apply, norm_mul]
  exact mul_le_of_le_one_left (norm_nonneg _) <| norm_le_one ..
```

```suggestion
  rcases eq_or_ne n 0 with hn | hn <;> simp [hn, ne_zero_of_one_lt_re hs]
```

This is shorter, but it almost doubles the heartbeats (from 458 to 867).
I am not really sure whether it is better to optimize the proof script (for length and readability) or the proof speed...
I've instead optmized the `simp only` calls somewhat.

> This is shorter, but it almost doubles the heartbeats (from 458 to 867). I am not really sure whether it is better to optimize the proof script (for length and readability) or the proof speed...

I am never quite sure either how these three priorities should be balanced. (I asked about this on zulip recently but no clear consensus seems to have emerged.) Given the lack of clarity on this, it is clearly up to PR authors to choose their priorities, so please don’t feel bound by my suggestion in any way.
`simp only` also works here (+ is slightly quicker I think)

This feels a bit roundabout, because the `simpa` call is performing basically the same set of simplifications as the `simp only` call. Here is a golfed version:
```suggestion
lemma convolution_vonMangoldt_zeta : ↗Λ ⍟ ↗ζ = ↗Complex.log := by
  ext n
  simpa [apply_ite, LSeries.convolution_def, ofReal_log n.cast_nonneg, -vonMangoldt_mul_zeta] 
    using congr_arg (ofReal' <| · n) vonMangoldt_mul_zeta
```
This makes it 1000 heartbeats slower, but squeezing the `simpa` makes the proof three times as fast as the original one.

No need to make `hs'` separately:
```suggestion
  have hf := LSeriesSummable_logMul_of_lt_re (show abscissaOfAbsConv 1 < s.re by
    rw [abscissaOfAbsConv_one]
    exact_mod_cast hs)
```

I've never been keen on `nth_rewrite`, it's hard to see at a glance what it's doing. What do you think of 
```suggestion
  suffices (↗χ * ↗Λ) ⍟ (↗χ * 1) = _ by rwa [mul_one] at this
```
instead?
Again, this is slower. I'm now doing it "right-to-left" in a single `rw` call.
why not `simpa only ... using ...`?
OK (20 heartbeats slower, though :smile:)

`convert` is a slow tactic, the following is twice as fast:
```suggestion
lemma LSeries_vonMangoldt_eq_deriv_riemannZeta_div {s : ℂ} (hs : 1 < s.re) :
    L ↗Λ s = - deriv riemannZeta s / riemannZeta s := by
  suffices deriv (L 1) s = deriv riemannZeta s by
    rw [LSeries_vonMangoldt_eq hs, ← LSeries_one_eq_riemannZeta hs, this]
  refine Filter.EventuallyEq.deriv_eq <| Filter.eventuallyEq_iff_exists_mem.mpr ?_
  exact ⟨{z | 1 < z.re}, (isOpen_lt continuous_const continuous_re).mem_nhds hs,
    fun _ hz ↦ (LSeries_one_eq_riemannZeta hz)⟩```
True; thanks!

This is equivalent, but more readable:
```suggestion
lemma term_congr {f g : ℕ → ℂ} (h : ∀ {n}, n ≠ 0 → f n = g n) (s : ℂ) (n : ℕ) :
```
